information.habitat: Found in tropical and subtropical oceans worldwide, often near coral reefs.
information.diet: Carnivorous apex predators that hunt a variety of fish.
information.behavior: Diurnal and fast-swimming hunters that use a sudden burst of speed to catch prey.

facts: Barracudas can reach speeds of up to 27 miles per hour.
They are attracted to shiny objects, which they may mistake for the scales of prey.
Great barracudas can grow up to 6 feet long.

name: Atlantic Bluefin Tuna
description: One of the largest, fastest, and most highly prized fish in the ocean, famous for its red meat.

information.habitat: Found across the North Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea.
information.diet: Carnivorous, feeding on a variety of fish, squid, and crustaceans.
information.behavior: They are highly migratory and can swim across entire ocean basins at great speeds.

facts: Atlantic bluefin tuna can grow up to 15 feet long and weigh over 1,500 pounds.
They are warm-blooded, which allows them to thrive in both warm and very cold waters.
Overfishing for the sushi and sashimi trade has led to a significant decline in their population.

name: Moray Eel
description: The Mediterranean moray is a long, serpent-like fish known for its powerful jaws and lack of scales.

information.habitat: Rocky reefs and caves across the Mediterranean Sea and Atlantic Ocean.
information.diet: Carnivorous, hunting fish and cephalopods like octopuses.
information.behavior: Nocturnal and reclusive, they spend the day in rocky crevices and use smell to find prey.

facts: Moray eels have a second set of jaws in their throat called pharyngeal jaws to help swallow prey.
They lack pelvic and pectoral fins, giving them their snake-like appearance.
Their skin is covered in a protective layer of slippery mucus.

name: Stingray
description: The Common Stingray is a cartilaginous fish with a flattened body and a long, whip-like tail with a venomous spine.

information.habitat: Sandy or muddy bottoms of coastal waters across the Atlantic and Mediterranean.
information.diet: Carnivorous, feeding on crustaceans, mollusks, and small fish.
information.behavior: Benthic (bottom-dwelling) animals that often bury themselves in the sand for camouflage.

facts: Stingrays use their venomous tail spine only for defense.
They are closely related to sharks, as both have a skeleton made of cartilage.
They have electroreceptors to help them find prey buried in the sand.

name: Swordfish
description: A large and powerful marine predator easily recognized by its long, flat 'sword' on its snout.

information.habitat: Found in temperate and tropical oceans worldwide, both in open water and near the coast.
information.diet: Carnivorous, eating a variety of fish and cephalopods like squid.
information.behavior: Highly migratory and extremely fast swimmers that use their sword to slash and stun prey.

facts: Swordfish can swim at speeds of up to 60 miles per hour.
Their sword is actually an extension of their upper jaw and is used for hunting.
They are famous for their ability to leap out of the water, a behavior called 'breaching'.

name: Mako Shark
description: The shortfin mako is a sleek and extremely fast species of shark found in the open ocean.

information.habitat: Found in temperate and tropical oceans worldwide in offshore waters.
information.diet: Carnivorous apex predators that hunt fast-swimming fish like tuna and swordfish.
information.behavior: Famous for their incredible speed and ability to leap high out of the water.

facts: The mako shark is the fastest species of shark, reaching speeds over 40 mph.
They are warm-blooded, which helps them maintain high energy levels for fast swimming.
Shortfin makos can leap up to 20 feet into the air.

name: Lionfish
description: A beautiful but venomous marine fish with long fins and distinctive red-and-white stripes.

information.habitat: Native to the Indo-Pacific but famously invasive in the Atlantic and Caribbean.
information.diet: Voracious predators that eat a variety of small fish and crustaceans.
information.behavior: They use their elaborate fins to herd prey and have venomous spines for protection.

facts: The spines of a lionfish contain a powerful venom that is very painful to humans.
Lionfish have become a major threat to coral reef ecosystems in the Atlantic.
They are also known as turkeyfish or butterfly cod.

name: Bottlenose Dolphin
description: Highly intelligent and social marine mammals with sleek gray bodies and a curved dorsal fin.

information.habitat: Found in temperate and tropical oceans worldwide, often in coastal areas.
information.diet: Carnivorous, primarily feeding on fish and squid.
information.behavior: Social animals that live in pods and communicate using a variety of whistles and clicks.

facts: Dolphins have individual 'signature whistles' that act like names.
They are famous for their playfulness and curiosity toward humans.
Dolphins use echolocation to navigate and find food.

name: Narwhal
description: A medium-sized whale native to the Arctic, famous for the male's long, spiraled tusk.

information.habitat: The icy waters of the Arctic Ocean, particularly around Canada and Greenland.
information.diet: Carnivorous, eating fish, squid, and shrimp.
information.behavior: Highly social whales that live in pods and are adapted to life in the deep, cold Arctic.

facts: The narwhal's tusk is actually an overgrown tooth that can be up to 10 feet long.
They are often called the 'unicorns of the sea'.
The tusk is a sensory organ with millions of nerve endings.

name: Beluga Whale
description: A small and social white whale native to the Arctic and sub-Arctic regions.

information.habitat: Coastal waters and river estuaries of the Arctic Ocean.
information.diet: Carnivorous, eating a variety of fish, crustaceans, and mollusks.
information.behavior: Highly social animals known as 'canaries of the sea' for their wide range of vocalizations.

facts: Beluga whales are born gray and turn white as they reach maturity.
They are the only whales that can move their head and neck independently.
They have a bulbous forehead called a 'melon' used for echolocation.

name: Sea Otter
description: A small marine mammal native to the North Pacific, famous for floating on its back and using tools.

information.habitat: Coastal waters of the North Pacific, particularly in kelp forests.
information.diet: Carnivorous, eating sea urchins, crabs, clams, and snails.
information.behavior: Social animals that often raft together; they use stones to break open hard-shelled prey.

facts: Sea otters have the densest fur of any animal in the world.
They play a vital role in kelp forest health by controlling sea urchin populations.
They often wrap themselves in kelp to prevent drifting away while they sleep.

name: Leatherback Sea Turtle
description: The largest of all living sea turtles, distinguished by its lack of a bony shell, which is replaced by leathery skin.

information.habitat: Found in all oceans worldwide, often in open water, and migrating long distances to nest.
information.diet: Strictly carnivorous, feeding almost exclusively on jellyfish.
information.behavior: Visual foragers that can dive to incredible depths in search of food.

facts: Leatherbacks can dive to depths of over 4,000 feet.
They are one of the most widely distributed reptiles on Earth.
A leatherback's shell is actually made of thousands of small bony plates covered in tough skin.

name: Galápagos Tortoise
description: The largest living tortoise species, famous for its long life and native only to the Galápagos Islands.

information.habitat: Arid and humid regions across the Galápagos Islands.
information.diet: Herbivorous, feeding on a variety of plants, including cacti and grasses.
information.behavior: Extremely slow-moving and long-lived; different islands have tortoises with differently shaped shells.

facts: Galápagos tortoises can live for over 150 years.
They were a key inspiration for Charles Darwin's theory of evolution.
They can survive for up to a year without food or water.

name: Great White Shark
description: A massive predatory shark species found in coastal surface waters of all major oceans.

information.habitat: Coastal and offshore temperate and tropical waters worldwide.
information.diet: Carnivorous apex predators that hunt fish, seals, and sea lions.
information.behavior: They are famous for their breaching behavior and have an incredible sense of smell.

facts: They can have up to 300 serrated teeth.
Great white sharks can detect a drop of blood in 25 gallons of water.
They are warm-blooded, which helps them move fast and hunt effectively.

name: Whale Shark

image_attribution.author: Derek Keats from Johannesburg, South Africa

description: The largest known fish species in the world, known for its gentle nature and unique spotted pattern.

information.habitat: Warm and tropical oceans worldwide, often found in open water.
information.diet: Filter feeders that primarily eat plankton and small fish.
information.behavior: Gentle giants that are known to be approachable by divers; they move slowly through the water.

facts: Whale sharks can grow up to 40 feet or more.
Each whale shark has a unique pattern of spots on its skin, like a fingerprint.
Despite their massive size, they are harmless to humans.

name: Clown Triggerfish
description: A beautifully colored marine fish known for its bold patterns of black, white, and yellow.

information.habitat: Tropical coral reefs across the Indo-Pacific region.
information.diet: Carnivorous, feeding on crustaceans, mollusks, and sea urchins.
information.behavior: Highly territorial and aggressive fish that use their strong teeth to crush hard shells.

facts: They have a special trigger spine on their back that they use to lock themselves into rocky crevices.
Clown triggerfish are popular but difficult to keep in aquariums due to their aggression.
Their bright patterns serve as a warning to other fish.

name: Anglerfish
description: The deep-sea anglerfish is famous for the bioluminescent lure on its head used to attract prey in the dark.

information.habitat: The dark, cold depths of all the world's oceans.
information.diet: Carnivores that eat other deep-sea fish and crustaceans.
information.behavior: Nocturnal ambush predators that use their glowing lure to attract unsuspecting prey.

facts: Only the females have the glowing lure on their head.
Male anglerfish are much smaller than females and become parasites by fusing to the female's body.
They have massive mouths and expandable stomachs to swallow large prey.

name: Blue Morpho Butterfly
description: A stunning tropical butterfly with iridescent blue wings and dark borders.

information.habitat: Tropical rainforests of Central and South America.
information.diet: Feed on rotting fruit and tree sap as adults.
information.behavior: Famous for the brilliant blue color of their wings, which is structural rather than pigmented.

facts: The blue color is caused by the way light reflects off the tiny scales on their wings.
The underside of their wings is brown with eyespots for camouflage.
They have a wingspan that can reach up to 8 inches.

name: Atlas Moth
description: One of the largest moth species in the world, native to Southeast Asia.

information.habitat: Tropical and subtropical forests of Southeast Asia.
information.diet: Adult moths do not have mouths and do not eat; caterpillars feed on a variety of leaves.
information.behavior: Nocturnal insects known for their massive wingspan and snake-like wing patterns.

facts: Atlas moths have a wingspan that can reach over 10 inches.
The tips of their wings are said to resemble snake heads to deter predators.
They live as adults for only one to two weeks.

name: Giant African Millipede
description: The Giant African Millipede is one of the largest species of millipede, growing up to 12 inches in length. It has a dark, cylindrical body with numerous segments and two pairs of legs per segment.

information.habitat: Tropical and subtropical rainforests and coastal habitats in East Africa.
information.diet: Herbivorous, primarily feeding on decaying organic matter, such as rotting wood and fallen leaves.
information.behavior: Generally slow-moving and non-aggressive; they roll into a tight spiral when threatened and can secrete a pungent liquid from their segments to deter predators.

facts: The Giant African Millipede can have up to 300 to 400 legs, despite the name 'millipede' meaning a thousand feet.
They have a symbiotic relationship with tiny mites that live on their exoskeleton and help keep it clean.
In the wild, they play a crucial role as decomposers, breaking down dead plant material.

name: Japanese Spider Crab
description: The Japanese spider crab has the largest leg span of any arthropod, reaching up to 12 feet from claw to claw. It has a bumpy, orange exoskeleton with white spots.

information.habitat: Found on the seabed in the Pacific Ocean around Japan, typically at depths of 150 to 1,000 feet.
information.diet: Omnivorous and opportunistic, feeding on animal carcasses, shellfish, and algae.
information.behavior: Known for their slow movements and longevity; they often decorate their shells with sponges or other marine life for camouflage.

facts: Japanese spider crabs can live for up to 100 years.
Despite their intimidating size, they are known to have a gentle disposition.
They are considered a delicacy in Japan but are subject to fishing regulations to protect their population.

name: Giant Panda
description: The giant panda is a bear native to south-central China, easily recognized by its large black patches around its eyes, over the ears, and across its round body.

information.habitat: Mountainous regions in central China, primarily in Sichuan, but also in neighboring Shaanxi and Gansu provinces.
information.diet: Herbivorous, with bamboo making up more than 99% of its diet, though it may occasionally eat other grasses or small rodents.
information.behavior: Solitary animals that spend most of their day eating and resting; they are excellent climbers and can swim if necessary.

facts: A giant panda's digestive system is more similar to that of a carnivore, despite its almost exclusive bamboo diet.
Newborn pandas are incredibly small, weighing about the same as a stick of butter.
Pandas have a 'sixth toe' on their paws, which is actually a modified wrist bone that helps them grip bamboo.

name: Snow Leopard
description: The snow leopard is a large cat with a thick, cream-colored coat featuring large black rosettes. It has an exceptionally long tail used for balance and warmth.

information.habitat: Alpine and subalpine zones in the mountain ranges of Central and South Asia, including the Himalayas.
information.diet: Carnivorous, primarily hunting wild sheep and goats like bharal and ibex, as well as smaller mammals.
information.behavior: Solitary and elusive 'ghosts of the mountains,' they are highly adapted for cold environments and steep terrain.

facts: Snow leopards cannot roar due to the physiology of their throats; instead, they make sounds like chuffs, mews, and growls.
Their long tails can be as long as their bodies and are used for balance on steep cliffs and as blankets in the cold.
Snow leopards have large, fur-covered paws that act as natural snowshoes.

name: Black Rhinoceros
description: The black rhinoceros is a large herbivore distinguished by its hooked upper lip, which is adapted for browsing on shrubs and trees.

information.habitat: Savannas, grasslands, and tropical bushlands in eastern and southern Africa.
information.diet: Herbivorous browser, eating a wide variety of plants, including leafy plants, branches, and thorny wood bushes.
information.behavior: Generally solitary and more aggressive than the white rhino; they have a keen sense of smell and hearing but poor eyesight.

facts: Black rhinos are actually gray, just like white rhinos.
They use their horns for defense, digging for water, and breaking branches.
Black rhinos can run at speeds up to 55 km/h.

name: Hawksbill Turtle
description: The hawksbill turtle is a sea turtle known for its hawk-like beak and unique shell pattern of overlapping scales, often harvested for tortoiseshell jewelry.

information.habitat: Tropical and subtropical waters of the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian Oceans, often found in coral reefs.
information.diet: Omnivorous, but primarily feeds on sea sponges; it also eats jellyfish and sea anemones.
information.behavior: Migratory creatures that return to the same beaches where they were born to lay their eggs.

facts: Hawksbill turtles play a vital role in maintaining the health of coral reefs by eating sea sponges.
Their shells change color slightly depending on the temperature of the water.
They can live up to 30-50 years in the wild.

name: Sumatran Tiger
description: The Sumatran tiger is the smallest surviving tiger subspecies, with darker orange fur and thicker black stripes than other subspecies.

information.habitat: Isolated pockets of tropical rainforest, mountains, and swamp forests on the island of Sumatra, Indonesia.
information.diet: Carnivorous, hunting wild boar, deer, and monkeys.
information.behavior: Solitary and territorial hunters; they are strong swimmers and may use water to corner prey.

facts: Sumatran tigers have webbed skin between their toes, which makes them excellent swimmers.
They are the only tiger subspecies found only on the island of Sumatra.
There are estimated to be fewer than 400 Sumatran tigers left in the wild.

name: Red Panda
description: The red panda is a small mammal with reddish-brown fur, a long shaggy tail, and a waddling gait due to its shorter front legs.

information.habitat: High-altitude temperate forests with bamboo understories in the Himalayas and other high mountains.
information.diet: Primarily herbivorous, eating bamboo, but also berries, fruits, and occasionally eggs or small birds.
information.behavior: Solitary and primarily nocturnal or crepuscular; they spend most of their time in trees and are highly agile.

facts: Red pandas are not closely related to giant pandas; they belong to their own unique family, Ailuridae.
They use their long, bushy tails for balance and as blankets to keep warm in the cold.
Red pandas have a 'false thumb,' which is an extension of the wrist bone that helps them grip bamboo.

name: African Forest Elephant
description: The African forest elephant is smaller than the bush elephant, with straighter tusks and more rounded ears.

information.habitat: Humid tropical forests of Central and West Africa.
information.diet: Herbivorous, consuming a variety of fruits, leaves, and bark; they play a crucial role in seed dispersal.
information.behavior: Live in smaller family groups than bush elephants; they are essential 'ecosystem engineers' of the rainforest.

facts: African forest elephants are a distinct species from African bush elephants.
They have straighter tusks that point downward, which helps them move through dense forest vegetation.
Forest elephants have a slower reproductive rate than other elephant species.

name: Green Sea Turtle
description: The green sea turtle is a large sea turtle with a wide, smooth shell; it is named for the green color of its fat, which comes from its diet.

information.habitat: Tropical and subtropical coastal waters around the world.
information.diet: Herbivorous as adults, feeding mainly on seagrasses and algae.
information.behavior: Known for long-distance migrations between feeding grounds and nesting beaches.

facts: Green sea turtles can stay underwater for up to five hours.
They are one of the largest species of sea turtles.
The gender of their offspring is determined by the temperature of the sand where the eggs are laid.

name: Blue Whale
description: The blue whale is the largest animal ever known to have existed, with a long, slender body that can be various shades of bluish-gray.

information.habitat: Found in all of the world's oceans except the Arctic.
information.diet: Carnivorous, feeding almost exclusively on tiny shrimp-like animals called krill.
information.behavior: Usually solitary or found in pairs; they communicate through loud, low-frequency sounds that can travel hundreds of miles.

facts: A blue whale's tongue can weigh as much as an elephant.
Their heart is the size of a bumper car.
Blue whales can consume up to 4 tons of krill in a single day.

name: Mountain Gorilla
description: The mountain gorilla has thicker and longer fur than other gorilla species, which helps it survive in high-altitude habitats.

information.habitat: Mountainous forests of central Africa.
information.diet: Primarily herbivorous, feeding on leaves, stems, and bamboo shoots.
information.behavior: Social animals living in family groups led by a dominant silverback.

facts: Mountain gorillas are one of our closest living relatives, sharing about 98% of our DNA.
They are highly intelligent and have been observed using tools and communicating through complex vocalizations.
The total population of mountain gorillas is estimated to be over 1,000 individuals.

name: Saola
description: Known as the 'Asian Unicorn,' the saola is a rare bovine with long, straight horns and striking white markings on its face.

information.habitat: Annamite Range forests of Vietnam and Laos.
information.diet: Herbivorous, browsing on small leafy plants and bushes.
information.behavior: Shy and secretive, rarely seen by humans; they are thought to be solitary or live in small groups.

facts: The saola was only discovered by scientists in 1992.
It is one of the rarest large mammals in the world.
Saolas have large scent glands on their muzzles used for marking territory.

name: Amur Leopard
description: The Amur leopard is a rare leopard subspecies with a thick, pale coat and large, widely spaced rosettes.

information.habitat: Temperate forests of the Russian Far East and Northeast China.
information.diet: Carnivorous, primarily hunting roe deer and sika deer.
information.behavior: Solitary and nocturnal; they are incredibly agile and known for their ability to carry heavy prey into trees.

facts: Amur leopards are one of the rarest big cats in the world.
Their thick fur can grow up to 7 cm long to help them survive harsh winters.
They are excellent climbers and can leap up to 19 feet horizontally.

name: Bornean Orangutan
description: The Bornean orangutan is a large ape with distinctive orange fur and a face that becomes more pronounced in adult males with cheek pads.

information.habitat: Tropical and subtropical moist broadleaf forests on the island of Borneo.
information.diet: Omnivorous, but primarily frugivorous, eating fruits like durian, as well as leaves and insects.
information.behavior: Primarily arboreal and solitary; they are highly intelligent and known for using tools.

facts: Orangutans share about 97% of their DNA with humans.
They have the longest childhood of any non-human animal, staying with their mothers for up to 8 years.
The name 'orangutan' comes from the Malay words 'orang' (person) and 'hutan' (forest).

name: Yangtze Finless Porpoise
description: This porpoise is unique for lacking a dorsal fin and having a highly developed intelligence, often referred to as the 'smiling angel' of the Yangtze.

information.habitat: The Yangtze River in China and its connecting lakes.
information.diet: Carnivorous, feeding on a variety of small fish and shrimp.
information.behavior: Social animals that live in small groups; they use echolocation to navigate and find food in murky water.

facts: Yangtze finless porpoises are one of the few species of freshwater porpoises.
They are known for their high intelligence, which is comparable to that of a gorilla.
Their population has been severely impacted by pollution, overfishing, and habitat loss.

name: Philippine Eagle
description: One of the largest and most powerful eagles in the world, with a shaggy crest and a massive blue-gray beak.

information.habitat: Old-growth tropical forests on the islands of the Philippines.
information.diet: Carnivorous, hunting monkeys, flying lemurs, and various reptiles.
information.behavior: Territorial and long-lived; they are loyal to their mates and typically raise only one chick every two years.

facts: The Philippine eagle is the national bird of the Philippines.
They have a wingspan that can reach up to 7 feet.
They are often referred to as 'monkey-eating eagles,' although their diet is more varied.

name: Vaquita
description: The vaquita is the world's smallest and most endangered cetacean, with dark rings around its eyes and mouth.

information.habitat: The northernmost part of the Gulf of California, Mexico.
information.diet: Carnivorous, feeding on small fish, squid, and crustaceans.
information.behavior: Extremely shy and elusive; they are often caught as bycatch in illegal gillnets.

facts: The vaquita is the rarest marine mammal in the world.
They were only discovered in 1958.
The name 'vaquita' means 'little cow' in Spanish.

name: Javan Rhino
description: A small rhinoceros with a single horn and skin that has loose folds, giving it an 'armored' appearance.

information.habitat: Dense tropical rainforests with plenty of water and mud wallows, currently only found in Ujung Kulon National Park, Indonesia.
information.diet: Herbivorous browser, feeding on a wide variety of plants and fruits.
information.behavior: Solitary and secretive; they are very dependent on wallowing in mud to regulate their body temperature.

facts: The Javan rhino is the rarest of the five rhino species.
Only the males have horns.
They are excellent swimmers and can cross rivers and even small stretches of ocean.

name: African Wild Dog
description: Also known as the painted dog, it has a unique coat of irregular patches of yellow, black, and white fur and large, rounded ears.

information.habitat: Savannas, grasslands, and open woodlands in sub-Saharan Africa.
information.diet: Carnivorous, hunting medium-sized ungulates like impalas and gazelles.
information.behavior: Highly social, living in packs with a complex social structure and cooperative hunting techniques.

facts: No two African wild dogs have the same coat pattern.
They are one of the most successful hunters in the animal kingdom, with a success rate of over 60%.
They are known for their complex vocalizations, including 'hoots' and 'chirps.'

name: Addax
description: A desert antelope with long, spiral horns and a coat that changes color from grayish-brown in winter to white in summer.

information.habitat: The Sahara Desert, adapted to survive in extreme arid conditions.
information.diet: Herbivorous, feeding on desert grasses and shrubs; they can survive for long periods without water.
information.behavior: Nomadic, traveling long distances in search of sparse vegetation; they are typically most active at night.

facts: Addax are highly adapted to life in the desert and can go for months without drinking water.
Their broad, flat hooves help them walk on soft sand without sinking.
Addax were once found across much of North Africa but are now restricted to a few small populations.
